guidelines.title: Code of Conduct
guidelines.description: Adhere to the project's code of conduct, fostering an inclusive, respectful, and collaborative community environment.

guidelines.title: Issue Reporting
guidelines.description: Detailed steps for reporting bugs or issues, including what information to include to help maintainers diagnose and resolve the problem quickly.

guidelines.title: Feature Requests
guidelines.description: Guidelines on how to suggest new features, providing a clear description, potential use cases, and benefits for the community.

guidelines.title: Pull Request Process
guidelines.description: Instructions on how to create and submit pull requests, including necessary checks, required reviews, and appropriate branching strategies.

guidelines.title: Coding Standards
guidelines.description: Specific coding style requirements and best practices to ensure consistency and readability in the codebase.

guidelines.title: Testing
guidelines.description: Requirements for writing and running tests before submitting contributions to ensure code quality and stability.

guidelines.title: Documentation
guidelines.description: Guide on documenting new features, changes, or general project details to help maintain up-to-date and comprehensive documentation.

guidelines.title: Communication Channels
guidelines.description: List of official channels for communication, such as forums, chat groups, or mailing lists, where contributors can ask questions, share ideas, or seek assistance.

guidelines.title: Fork the Repository
guidelines.description: Fork the main repository to your GitHub account to have your own copy for making changes. This ensures you have a separate space to work on without affecting the original project, and it simplifies the process of submitting contributions through pull requests.

guidelines.title: Create a Branch
guidelines.description: Create a new branch for your changes, distinct from the main branch. This helps in isolating your work and makes it easier to manage and review different sets of changes. It also minimizes conflicts when merging changes back into the main project.

guidelines.title: Write Clear Commits
guidelines.description: Make sure to write clear and concise commit messages that describe the changes you have made. Good commit messages make it easier for other contributors to understand the history of changes and the context behind them.

guidelines.title: Update Documentation
guidelines.description: If your changes affect or require updates to the project's documentation, make those updates as part of your pull request. This ensures that the documentation remains up-to-date and useful for all users.

guidelines.title: Run Tests
guidelines.description: Before submitting your contributions, run all existing tests and add new tests if necessary. This helps in ensuring that your changes do not break existing functionality and that new features work as intended.

guidelines.title: Submit a Pull Request
guidelines.description: Once your changes are complete and thoroughly tested, submit a pull request to the original repository. Provide a detailed description of your changes, what problem they solve, and any other relevant information. This allows project maintainers to review and integrate your changes.

guidelines.title: Follow Coding Standards
guidelines.description: Adhere to the coding standards and style guidelines established by the project. Consistent code style and standards improve readability and maintainability of the codebase.

guidelines.title: Be Respectful and Collaborative
guidelines.description: Engage respectfully with other contributors and project maintainers. Collaboration and respectful communication are key to the success of any open-source project.

guidelines.title: File Issues for Bugs
guidelines.description: If you find a bug, file an issue before working on a fix, unless the contribution guidelines suggest otherwise. This helps in tracking the problem and discussing potential solutions with project maintainers.
